 Given n = 64
 Substituting in the formula:
 (720/11 - 64)(12x 60)/64
 720-704/11 * (12*60)/64
 16/11 * 45/4
 4/11*45
 180/11

 Next coincidence will be at 9:45; The exact time is 45*12/11 = 9:49:01

Question_Text: A watch loses 2 minutes in every 24 hours while another watch gains 2 minutes in every 24 hours. At a particular instant, the two watchers showed an identical time. Which of the following statements is correct if 24 - hour clock is followed?
choice_1: The two watches show the identical time again on completion of 30 days.
choice_2: The two watches show the identical time again on completion of 90 days.
choice_3: The two watches show the identical again on completion of 120 days.
choice_4: None of the above statements is correct.
Solution:
A watch loses 2 minutes in every 24 hours, while another watch gains 2 minutes in every 24 hours. 
 Therefore, every day(24 hours) the time difference between the two watches will keep on 
 increasing by 4 minutes. This means that the two watches will again show the same 
 identical time when this difference increases to 24 hours, i.e. 
 24 x 60 minutes 1440 minutes. 
 By unitary method, 
 The difference of 4 minutes is reached in 1 day. 
 The difference of 1 minutes is reached in 1/4 day. 
 The difference of 1440 minutes is reached in 1440/4 — 360 days. 
 Hence, None of the above statements is correct.

Question_Text: The minor angle between the hours hand and minutes hand of a clock was observed at 8:48 am. The minimum duration, in minutes, after 8.48 am when this angle increases by 50% is
Solution:
FINDING ANGLES
 If ‘HH:MM’ given,
 HH x 30˚ - HH x 11/2˚
 08 x 30˚ - 48 x 11/2˚ 
 240 ˚ - 264 ˚ = 24˚ (angle < 180˚)
 ∴ angle increases by 50% 
 150% of 24 = 36˚
 Increase angle from 264˚ to 276˚
 48 x 11/2˚ = 264 and X x 11/2˚ =276
 264/48 = 276/x;
 By solving the above two terms, we get
 X = 552/11 ~ 50 (2/11) min
 minimum duration, in minutes, after 8.48 am when this angle increases by 50% is = 50 (2/11) min – 48 min = 24/11

Question_Text: In 2016, Mohan celebrated his birthday on Friday. Which will be the firstyear after 2016 when Mohan will celebrate his birthday on a Wednesday? (He was not born in January or February)
Solution:
Since it has been mentioned that Mohan was not born in February, so he can’t be born on 2 
 9th Feb. Hence He will celebrate his next birthday on a Wednesday in the year for which th 
 e sum of the odd days becomes 5 or a multiple of 5. 
 By his birthday in 2017, there will be 1 odd day. 
 By his birthday in 2018, there will be 2 odd days. 
 By his birthday in 2019, there will be 3 odd days. 
 By his birthday in 2020, there will be 5 odd days, as 2020 is a leap year. 
 So in 2020 He will celebrate his birthday on Wednesday.

Question_Text: John was born on Feb 29th of 2012 which happened to be a Wednesday. If he lives to be 101 years old, how many birthdays would he celebrate on a Wednesday?
Solution:
Let us do this iteratively. Feb 29th 2012 = Wednesday => Feb 28th 2012 = Tuesday
 Feb 28th 2013 = Thursday (because 2012 is a leap year, there will be 2 odd days)
 Feb 28th 2014 = Friday, Feb 28th 2015 = Saturday, Feb 28th 2016 = Sunday, Feb 29th 2016 = Monday
 Or, Feb 29th to Feb 29th after 4 years, we have 5 odd days.
 
 So, every subsequent birthday, would come after 5 odd days.
 2016 birthday – 5 odd days
 2020 birthday – 10 odd days = 3 odd days
 2024 birthday – 8 odd days = 1 odd day
 2028 birthday – 6 odd days
 2032 birthday – 11 odd days = 4 odd days
 2036 birthday – 9 odd days = 2 odd days
 2040 birthday – 7 odd days = 0 odd days. So, after 28 years he would have a birthday on Wednesday
 
 The next birthday on Wednesday would be on 2068 (further 28 years later), the one after that would be on 2096. His 84th birthday would again be a leap year.
 
 Now, there is a twist again, as 2100 is not a leap year. So, he does not have a birthday in 2100. His next birthday in 2104 would be after 9 odd days since 2096, or 2 odd days since 2096, or on a Thursday.
 
 From now on the same pattern continues. 2108 would be 2 + 5 odd days later = 7 odd days later. Or, 2108 Feb 29th would be a Wednesday.
 So, there are 4 occurrences of birthday falling on Wednesday – 2040, 2068, 2096 and 2108.
 
 The question is "How many birthdays would he celebrate on a Wednesday?"
 
 Hence, the answer is "4".

Question_Text:
How many of the following statements have to be true?
 i. No year can have 5 Sundays in the month of May and 5 Thursdays in the month of June.
 ii. If Feb 14th of a certain year is a Friday, May 14th of the same year cannot be a Thursday
 iii. If a year has 53 Sundays, it can have 5 Mondays in the month of May.
Solution:
If Feb 14th of a certain year is a Friday, May 14th of the same year cannot be a Thursday
 From Feb 14 to Mar 14, there are 28 or 29 days, 0 or 1 odd day
 Mar 14 to Apr 14, there are 31 days, or 3 odd days
 Apr 14 to May 14 there are 30 days or 2 odd days
 So, Feb 14 to May 14, there are either 5 or 6 odd days
 So, if Feb 14 is Friday, May 14 can be either Thursday or Wednesday. So, statement II need not be true.

Question_Text:
A year 1895 is having a same calendar as that of the year X. 
 Which of the following is a possible value of X.
Solution:
1895 is not a leap year. It has 1 odd day.
 Since 1896 is a leap year, it will add 2 odd days.
 Similarly 1987, 1898, 1899, 1900 will add 1,1,1,1 odd days.
 Now the total number of odd days add up to 7.
 So the next year 1901 will have the same calendar as 1895.

Two cars start from the opposite places of a main road, 150 km
  apart. First car runs for 25 km and takes a right turn and then runs 
 15 km. It then turns left and then runs for another 25 km and then
  takes the direction back to reach the main road. In the mean time, 
 due to minor break down the other car has run only 35 km along
  the main road. What would be the distance between two cars at 
 this point?
Solution:
Distance between starting points = 150 km.
 
 Journey of first bus = 25 km, then takes a right turn and then runs for 15 km, then turns left and runsfor another 25 km and takes the direction back to reach the main road.
 
 
 Journey of second bus = 35 km along the main road
 
 Calculations:
 
 Let first bus started from point X.
 
 After running for 25 km, it reaches point A.
 Then took a right turn and then runs for 15 km.
  After reaching point B, turns left and runs parallel to main road for another 25 km.
 After reaching point C, takes the left turn and reached the main road at point D
 
 Total distance covered by the first bus along main road = 25 + 25 = 50 km
 
 Let second bus started from point Y.
 
  Due to a minor breakdown, the second bus has run only 35 km along the main road and reached point E.
 
 Total distance covered by the second bus along main road = 35 km
 
 Distance between both the buses = 150 - (50 + 35)= 150 - 85= 65 km
 
 :. The distance between the two buses at the end is 65 km.

Question_Text: A man walks in the directions given below(i) 50 m to East (ii) then 50 m to South (iii) and then 120 m to West (iv)later 25 m to North (v) and finally 70 m to East Then the distance (in meters) between the starting point and the last point is?
Suresh walked 90 metres towards South and moves 85 m towards East and then moves a distance of 50 m towards North and then moves 45 m towards West. The distance from the starting point is?
Solution:
Here's the journey:
 - South: 90 m
 - East: 85 m
 - North: 50 m
 - West: 45 m
 Vertical (North-South):
 - South: 90 m
 - North: 50 m
 - Net vertical movement:
 90 - 50 = 40 m South
 ➡️ Horizontal (East-West):
 - East: 85 m
 - West: 45 m.
 So, he ends up 40 meters south and 40 meters east of the starting point.
 Total Distance from Starting Point
 Using the Pythagorean theorem:
 \text{Distance} = \sqrt{(40)^2 + (40)^2} = \sqrt{1600 + 1600} = \sqrt{3200} \approx \boxed{56.57 \text{ meters}}
 
 ✅ Final Answer
 Suresh is approximately 56.57 meters away from his starting point.

A cube of side 125 cm is painted red on all the faces and then cut into smaller cubes of sides 25 cm each. Find the number of smaller cubes having at least two faces painted.
Solution:
Length of the side of the big cube = 125 cm.
Length of the side of the smaller cube = 25 cm.

n = No. of parts of each side  Length of the side of the larger cube + length of the side of the smaller cube

n = 125/ 25 = 5

n - 2 = 3

Number of smaller cubes having at least two faces painted = total no. of cubes - (no. of cubes with no face painted + no. of cubes with only one face painted)

 125 - (3^3 + 6 × 3^2)

 125 - (27 + 54)

 125 - 81= 44

Hence, 44 is the correct answer.

Question_Text: A cuboid of dimensions 4 in.* 6 in.* 7 in. is painted on all six faces with the same colour. It is then completely cut into identical small cubes, each side 1 in. What is the ratio of the number of cubes with no face painted to the number of cubes with exactly one face painted to those with exactly two faces painted?
Solution:
Size of the cuboid = 4 x 6 x 7

For cubes with no face colored:

We need to remove a layer of cubes from the top, bottom, left, right, front and back.
The resulting figure will have no color.

Number of cubes with 0 side painted = (a-2) (b-2) (c-2)

Thus, number of cubes = (4 - 2) x (6 - 2) x (7 - 2) = 40 cubes

For cubes with one face colored:

We need to find the central areas of each face (shown in gray in the image). Thus, there would be:

Number of cubes with 1 sides painted  = 2[(a-2) (b-2) + (b-2)(c-2) + (a-2)(c-2) ]

2 faces with (4 - 2) x (6 - 2) = 8 *2 cubes each => 16 cubes
2 faces with (7 - 2) x (6 - 2) = 20* 2 cubes each => 40 cubes
2 faces with (7 - 2) x (4 - 2) = 10*2  cubes each => 20 cubes
Thus, number of cubes = 16 + 40 + 20 = 76 cubes

For cubes with two faces colored:

We need to find the number of cubes along the edges (shown in brown in the image):
(Note: We should ignore the corners, since the corners are cubes with 3 faces colored)

There are 12 edges - 4 edges with 7 cubes along it, 4 edges with 6 cubes along it and 4 edges with 4 cubes along it. Thus, we have:

Number of cubes with 2 sides painted =  4(a+b+c -6)

4 edges with (4 - 2) = 2 cubes each => 8 cubes
4 edges with (6 - 2) = 4 cubes each => 16 cubes
4 edges with (7 - 2) = 5 cubes each => 20 cubes

Thus, number of cubes = 8 + 16 + 20 = 44 cubes

=> Required ratio = 40 : 76 : 44 = 10 : 19 : 11

Question_Text:
Car A is moving behind car B in the same direction and the distance between them initially is 40 km and the speed of car B is 50 km/hr, then how long would car A take to cross car B.[Assume the length of the cars to be negligible] 

Statements 1:  The time taken car B to cover a distance of 200 km is 4 hours.
Statements 2: If the cars were moving in the opposite directions, towards each other, the relative speed of car A with respect of car B would have been 120 km/hr.
choice_1: If the data in statement I alone is sufficient to answer the question, while the data in statement II alone is not sufficient to answer the question
choice_2: If the data in statement II alone is sufficient to answer the question, while the data in statement I alone is not sufficient to answer the question
choice_3: If the data either in statement I alone or statement II alone is  sufficient to answer the question
choice_4: If the data in both statement I and II together are neccessary to answer the question
Solution:
Statement 1  again we are finding speed of car B

Satement 2: 

the sum of their speeds is 120 km/hr.
Since car B's speed is 50 km/hr, car A's speed is  120−50=70 km/hr.
Now, with car A's speed (70 km/hr) and car B's speed (50 km/hr), the relative speed when moving in the same direction is 70−50=20 km/hr.
To find the time taken for car A to cross car B, we use the formula:
Time=Distance​/Relative Speed=40 km/20 km/hr​=2 hours

Question_Text:
`Is the average age of the students of a school less than 17 years?
Statement I : The strength of the class VIII is less than 25% of the strength of the school.
Statement II : The average age of the students of class VIII of the school is 18 years and that of the remaining classes is 16 years.
choice_1: If the data in statement I alone is sufficient to answer the question, while the data in statement II alone is not sufficient to answer the question
choice_2: If the data in statement II alone is sufficient to answer the question, while the data in statement I alone is not sufficient to answer the question
choice_3: If the data either in statement I alone or statement II alone is  sufficient to answer the question
choice_4: If the data in both statement I and II together are neccessary to answer the question
Solution:
Total number of students in the school = S (ASSUME = 1000)
Number of students in class VIII =C (= 25%  250)
Therefore, number of students in remaining classes = S – C ( 750)
The overall average age (A) can be calculated as:
A = [250 * 18 + 750* 16] / 1000
We can simplify this:A = 16.5
We want to know if A < 17:
Since 16.5 is definitely less than 17, combining both statements tells us that the average age is less than 17.

Question_Text:
What will be the total weight of 10 poles, each of the same weight? 
Statement 1: One-fourth of the weight of each pole is 5 kg. Statement 2: The total weight of three poles is 20 kilograms more than the total weight of two poles.
choice_1: I alone is sufficient while II alone is not sufficient
choice_2: II alone is sufficient while I alone is not sufficient
choice_3: Either I or II is sufficient
choice_4: Neither I nor II is sufficient
Solution:
If one-fourth of the weight of each pole is 5 kg, then the full weight of each pole is 4×5=204×5=20 kg.
Therefore, the total weight of 10 poles is 10×20=20010×20=200 kg.

Statement 2: The total weight of three poles is 20 kilograms more than the total weight of two poles.

According to the statement, 3x=2x+20
                x=20 kg.
Therefore, the total weight of 10 poles is 10×20=200 kg.

Question_Text:
A company has three departments: Marketing (M), Sales (S), and Finance (F). The total number of employees is 100. The ratio of employees in M: S: F is 2:3:5.
 
Questions:
How many employees are in the Sales department?
Solution:
Total ratio parts: 2 + 3 + 5 = 10 parts
Employees in each part: 100 employees / 10 parts = 10 employees per part
Employees in Sales: 3 parts * 10 employees/part = 30 employees
Percentage in Finance: (5/10) * 100% = 50%
Female employees in Marketing: (20/100) * (2 * 10) = 4 female employees

Question_Text:
Read the following information carefully and answer the given questions:
There are two boxes A and B that contain the three different colours of balls i.e. red, yellow and green and the total number of balls in both boxes is 80. The ratio of the total number of balls in box A to box B is 5:3. 30% of the total number of balls is red. The ratio of the number of red balls in box A to box B is 7:5. The number of yellow balls in A is 2 more than the number of red balls in A. The ratio of the number of red balls in B to the number of green balls in B is 5:4.                                                                                        Question:   Number of red balls in A is what percent of the number of green balls in A?
Solution:
Total number of balls in A=5/8 * 80=50               
Total number of balls in B=3/8 * 80=30
Total number of red balls=30/100 * 80=24
Number of red balls in A=7/12 * 24=14
Number of red balls in B=5/12 * 24=10
Number of yellows in A=14 + 2=16
Number of green balls in A=50 – 14 – 16=20
Number of green balls in B=4/5 * 10=8
Number of yellow balls in B=30 – 10 – 8=12                                                                                                                         Required percentage = 14/20 * 100 = 70%

Number of female employees in sales department=600 – 420=180
Required ratio=420:180
=7:3

Question_Text:
Study the following information carefully and answer the questions given below:
A company manufactured some products in the years 2012 and 2013. In 2012, the company manufactured 60% of non-defected products and 30% with minor defects. 30000 units have been completely disposed of due to severe defects. Question: What is the ratio of completely disposed product manufactured in 2012 to 2013?
Solution:
2012:
Completely disposed = 10% = 30000
Non defective = 60% = 180000
Minor defective = 30% = 90000
Total products manufactured = 300000
2013:
Non defective = 1/3 x 180000 = 60000
Minor defective = 20/100 x 90000 = 18000
Completely disposed = 10/100 x 180000 = 18000
Total products manufactured = 96000
Completely disposed product of 2012 = 30000
Completely disposed product of 2013 = 18000
Required Ratio = 5:3

Question_Text:
Study the following information carefully and answer the questions given below.
There are four different stores A, B, C and D which sold two different products Shampoo and Soap. Number of soaps sold in B and D is in the ratio of 4:1. Total number of shampoos sold in C is double the total number of shampoos sold in B, which is 200 less than the total number of shampoos sold in A. Number of soaps sold in A is same as the number of shampoos sold in C. Total number of shampoos sold in D is 33(1/3)% of the total number of shampoos sold in A. Average number of soaps sold in all the stores together is 625, which is 175 more than the total number of soaps sold in C. The difference between the number of soaps sold in B and D is 750.
Question: If the ratio of the number of detergent soaps and kitchen soaps sold in A is 5:3 and only detergent soaps and kitchen soaps are sold in A, then what is the difference between the number of detergent and kitchen soaps sold in A?
Solution:
Explanation
Number of shampoos sold in B = x
Number of shampoos sold in C = 2 * x = 2x
Number of shampoos sold in A = x + 200
Number of shampoos sold in D = 100/300 * (x + 200)
Number of soaps sold in A = 2x
Number of soaps sold in B = 4/3 * 750 = 1000
Number of soaps sold in D = 1/3 * 750 = 250
Number of soaps sold in C = 625 – 175 = 450
Number of soaps sold in A = 625 * 4 – 1000 – 250 – 450 = 800
Number of shampoos sold in C = 800
Number of shampoos sold in B = 800/2 = 400
Number of shampoos sold in A = 400 + 200 = 600
Number of shampoos sold in D = 600/3 = 200

Question_Text: A, B, and C together can complete a task in 10 days. A is twice as efficient as B and three times as efficient as C. How long will B and C together take to finish the task?
Solution:
A, B, and C together can complete the task in 10 days.Let the total work = WThe combined efficiency of A, B, and C = 6x+3x+2x=11x
W=Total Work=Efficiency×Time=11x×10=110x
The efficiency of B and C together = 3x+2x=5x
Time taken B and C = Total Work Efficiency of B and C/{Total Work}=110X/5X=22 days
Topic: TIME AND WORK (WORK WITH DIFFERENT EFFICIENCIES)

Question_Text: A can complete a task in 16 days, and B can complete it in 20 days. They work together for 6 days, and then A leaves. If C, who is twice as efficient as B, joins B, how many more days are required to finish the task?
Solution:
Total Work= LCM of 16 and 20=80units
The efficiency of A = 80 /16=5 units/day
Efficiency of A and B=5+4=9units/day
Work done by A and B in 6 days=6×9=54units.
Remaining Work=80−54=26 units
C is twice as efficient as B, so the efficiency of C is:
2×4=8 units/day.
The combined efficiency of B and C is:
4+8=12 units/day
Time required = Remaining Work/Efficiency=26/12=2.17 days
Topic: TIME AND WORK (WORK WITH DIFFERENT EFFICIENCIES)

Question_Text: C is 50% more efficient than D, and they together can complete a task in 9 days. How long will D take to complete the same task working alone?
Solution:
Let the efficiency of D be xSince C is 50% more efficient than D, the efficiency of C will be 1.5x
Total Work=2.5x×9=22.5x
Time taken by D alone=Efficiency of D/Total Work​=22.5X/X=22.5days.
Topic: TIME AND WORK (WORK WITH DIFFERENT EFFICIENCIES)

Question_Text: A is twice as efficient as B and completes a task in 12 days working alone. If A and B work together for 4 days and then B leaves, how many more days will A take to complete the task?
Solution:
Efficiency of A=Total work/total time=1/12
Efficiency of B=1/2×Efficiency of A=1/2x1/12(tasks/day)=1/24

Time taken by A to complete remaining work=Efficiency of A/Remaining Work​=12x1/2​​=6 days

Question_Text: A and B can complete a task in 8 days, and B and C can complete the same task in 12 days. A, B, and C together can complete the task in 6 days. How many days will A and C together take to complete the task?
Solution:
Total Work= lcm 0f  8,12,6 =24 units.
Efficiency of A + B=Total Work​/time=24/8​=3 units/day
Efficiency of B + C=Total Work/total time=24/12​=2 units/day
Efficiency of A + B + C=Total Work/total time=24/6​= 4units/day
Efficiency of C=(Efficiency of A + B + C)−(Efficiency of A + B)=4−3=1unit/day
Efficiency of A=(Efficiency of A + B + C)−(Efficiency of B + C)=4−2=2units/day.
Efficiency of A + C=Efficiency of A+Efficiency of C=2+1=3units/day
Time taken by A and C together=Total Work/efficiency of A and C​=24/3=8 days
Topic: TIME AND WORK (WORK WITH DIFFERENT EFFICIENCIES)

Question_Text: A can complete a task in 12 days, while B can complete the same task in 16 days. Both A and B start working together, but after 4 days, C, whose efficiency is equivalent to that of B, joins them. In how many days will the task be completed?
Solution:
Efficiency of A=Total Work/total time​=1/12​(tasks/day
Efficiency of B=Total Work/time​=1/16​(tasks/day)
Efficiency of C=1/16​(tasks/day)
Work done by A and B in 4 days=Efficiency of( A + B)×114=(1/12+1/16)x4=7/48 x4=7/12
Remaining Work=1−7/12​=​5/12
Efficiency of A + B + C=1/12+1/16+1/16​=5/24
Time taken to complete the remaining work=5/12 /5/24=2
Total Time=4+2=6 days

Question_Text: A, B, and C can complete a task in 10 days when working together. The efficiency of A is equivalent to twice that of B, and the efficiency of C is equivalent to half that of A. How long will B and C together take to complete the task?
Solution:
Let the efficiency of B be x (work done per day by B).
The efficiency of A is twice that of B, so Efficiency of A=2x
The efficiency of C is half that of A, so Efficiency of C=1/2 (2x)=x
Efficiency of A + B + C=2x+x+x=4x=1/10
X=1/40
Efficiency of B + C=x+x=2x=2×1/40​=1/20.
Time taken by B and C=1/1/20​=20 days
Topic: TIME AND WORK (WORK WITH DIFFERENT EFFICIENCIES)

Question_Text: A, B, and C can complete a task in 6 days when working together. A works for 3 days, and B works for 4 days, after which C completes the remaining work in 2 days. If the efficiency of A is equivalent to that of B, and C’s efficiency is half that of A, how many days would C alone take to complete the task?

Efficiency of A + B + C=x+x+x/2=2x+x/2=5x/2=1/6
X=1/15
Efficiency of C = x/2=1/30
thus, time taken by C to complete the entire task in 30 days
Topic: TIME AND WORK (WORK WITH DIFFERENT EFFICIENCIES)

Question_Text: A and B can complete a task in 10 days. C, whose efficiency is equivalent to twice that of B, can complete the same task in 15 days. How many days will A, B, and C together take to complete the task?
Solution:
Efficiency of A + B=Total work/total time​=1/10​(tasks/day).
Efficiency of C=Total work/total time​=1/15
Efficiency of A + B + C=1/10+1/15=1/6
Time taken by A, B, and C together=6 days
Topic: TIME AND WORK (WORK WITH DIFFERENT EFFICIENCIES)

Question_Text: A, B, and C can complete a task in 12 days, 15 days, and 18 days respectively. Their efficiency is in the ratio of their equivalence relation with another group D, E, and F, where D is twice as efficient as B, E is equivalent to A, and F is 50% more efficient than C. If D, E, and F work together, how many days will they take to complete the same task?
Solution:
Total Work=LCM(12,15,18)=180units
Efficiency of A = Total work/total time=180/12=15 units/d
Efficiency of B = Total Work/total time=180/15=12 units/day
Efficiency of C = Total Work/Time =180/18=10 units/day
Efficiency of D=2×Efficiency of B=2×12=24units/day
Efficiency of E=Efficiency of A=151units/day
Efficiency of F=1.5×Efficiency of C=1.5×10=15units/day
Efficiency of D + E + F=24+15+15=54units/day
The time required to complete the task is:
Time=Total Work/Efficiency of D + E + F=180/54=10/3 days=3.3 days
Topic: TIME AND WORK (WORK WITH DIFFERENT EFFICIENCIES)

Question_Text:
X, Y, and Z together can finish a piece of work in [P/13] days, while X and Y together
can do it in [P/10] days. Y alone can complete the same work in [P/4] days. Z takes
20 days more than X to complete the work alone. What is the value of P?
Solution:
One day work of X, Y & Z together = 13/P
One day work of X & Y together = 10/ P
One day work of Z = 13 / P - 10/ P = 3 /P
Time taken by Z alone to complete the work = P/3 days
One day work of X & Y together = 10/P
One day work Y = 4 / P
One day work X = 10 /P - 4 /P = 6 /P
Time taken by X alone to complete the work = P / 6 days
ATQ, P/ 3 - P /6 = 20
or, P/ 6 = 20
So, P = 120
Topic: TIME AND WORK (WORK WITH DIFFERENT EFFICIENCIES)

Question_Text: Two pipes can fill a tank in 20 and 24 minutes respectively and a waste pipe can empty 3 gallons per minute. All the three pipes working together can fill the tank in 15 minutes. The capacity of the tank is:
Solution:
Solution:
Work done by the waste pipe in 1 minute = (1/15) - [(1/20)+(1/24)] 
                                                                    = -1/40. 
Volume of 1/40 part = 3 gallons.
 Volume of whole = (3 x 40) gallons 
                              = 120 gallons.

Question_Text: A tank is filled in 5 hours by three pipes A, B and C. The pipe C is twice as fast as B and B is twice as fast as A. How much time will pipe A alone take to fill the tank?
Solution:
Solution:
Let A takes x hours. 
Then B = x/2, C = x/4. 
1/x + 1/(x/2) + 1/(x/4) = 1/5 
=> 7/x = 1/5 
=> x = 35 hrs.

Question_Text: Two pipes A and B together can fill a cistern in 4 hours. Had they been opened separately, then B would have taken 6 hours more than A to fill the cistern. How much time will be taken by A to fill the cistern separately?
Solution:
Solution:
Let A fill in x hrs, 
then B in x+6 hrs. 
1/x + 1/(x+6) = ¼
 => (x + x + 6)/(x(x + 6)) = 1/4 
=> x^2 - 2x - 24 = 0 
=> (x+4) (x-6) = 0
=> x = 6

Question_Text: Two pipes A and B can fill a tank in 15 minutes and 20 minutes respectively. Both the pipes are opened together but after 4 minutes, pipe A is turned off. What is the total time required to fill the tank?
Solution:
Solution:
Part filled in 4 minutes = 4(1/15 + 1/20) = 7/15
Remaining part = 1 - 7/15 = 8/15
Part filled by B in 1 minute = 1/20
Time to fill 8/15 = (8/15) × 20 = 10 min 40 sec
Total time = 4 min + 10 min 40 sec = 14 min 40 sec

Question_Text: One pipe can fill a tank three times as fast as another pipe. If together the two pipes can fill the tank in 36 minutes, then the slower pipe alone will be able to fill the tank in
Solution:
Ratio of efficiency of two pipes = 3 : 1

Total work = (3+1)*36  4*36  144 

Time take by slower pipe = 144/1  144


Or 


Let the slower pipe alone fill the tank in x minutes.
Then, faster pipe will fill it in x/3 minutes.
(1/x + 1/(x/3)) = 1/36
=> (4/x) = 1/36 => x = 144 minutes

Question_Text: A tap can fill a tank in 6 hours. After half the tank is filled, three more similar taps are opened. What is the total time taken to fill the tank completely?
Solution:
Solution:
Time to fill half tank with one tap = 3 hrs
Remaining = 1/2 tank
Four taps together fill 4 × (1/6) = 2/3 tank/hour
Time = (1/2) ÷ (2/3) = 3/4 hrs = 45 mins
Total time = 3 hrs + 45 mins = 3 hrs 45 mins

Question_Text: Three pipes A, B and C can fill a tank in 6 hours. After working at it together for 2 hours, C is closed and A and B can fill the remaining part in 7 hours. The number of hours taken by C alone to fill the tank is:
Solution:
Solution:
Part filled in 2 hrs = 2/6 = 1/3
Remaining = 1-1/3 = 2/3
A + B fill 2/3 in 7 hrs 
=> A + B in 1 hr = 2/21

A + B + C = 1/6
C = (A+B+C) –(A+B)
C = 1/6 - 2/21 = 1/14 
=> C alone fills in 14 hrs

Question_Text: A tank is filled by three pipes with uniform flow. The first two pipes operating simultaneously fill the tank in the same time during which the tank is filled by the third pipe alone. The second pipe fills the tank 5 hours faster than the first pipe and 4 hours slower than the third pipe. Time required by the first pipe to fill the tank is
Solution:
Solution:
Let first pipe fill in x hours. 
Then second in (x - 5), third in (x - 9)

1/x + 1/(x - 5) = 1/(x - 9)

(x-5) + x /x(x-5) = 1/(x-9)
(2x - 5) (x -9)=x(x -5)
2x^2 - 5x - 18x +45=x^2-5x
X^2 - 18x +45=0
(x - 15) (x -3)=0
x = 15 [neglecting x = 3]
So time required by 1st pipe = 15 hours

Question_Text: There are two outlet pipes connected to a tank which can empty the tank in 2 hours and 3 hours respectively. There is an inlet pipe connected to the tank, which can fill it in 6 hours. Both the outlet pipes are opened when the tank is full. But by mistake, someone opened the inlet pipe when the tank was exactly half empty. Calculate the delay in time taken to empty the tank.

There are four pipes joined in a tank where pipe C only outlet pipe. Pipe C
and Pipe A together filled the tank in 24 hours. Pipe A and B together fill
the tank in 7.2 hours. Pipe B is double efficient than pipe D. Pipe A and D
together filled the tank in [x +3] hours. Pipe A fill the tank alone in 12
hours. Find how part pipe B and D fill the tank in x hours?
Solution:
Let the capacity of the tank = 1 unit
Pipe A fills the tank alone in 12 hours
Efficiency of A = 1/12
Pipe C and A together fill the tank in 24 hours
That means:
A's rate + C's rate = 1/24
Substitute A's rate:
1/12 + C = 1/ 24
C= 1/24-1/12 = [1 - 2] / 24 = -1/ 24
Pipe C is an outlet pipe (as stated), and it empties at the rate of 1/24
A and B together fill the tank in 7.2 hours
1/A + 1/B = 1/7.2
Or, 1/12 + 1/B = 1/7.2
Or, 1/B = 10/72 - 1/12 = [10- 6] / 72 = 1/18
Pipe B fills at 1/18 per hour.
B is double efficient than D
Pipe D fills at 1/36 per hour.
A and D together fill in x + 3 hours
1/A + 1/D = 1/(x+3)
= 1/12 + 1/36 = 1/(x+3)
Or, 4/36 = 1 /(x+3)
Or, x + 3 = 9 , x= 6
We know:
B = 1/ 18 , D = 1/36
Together they fill at in rate of [ 1/18 + 1/ 36 = 3 /36 = 1/12]
So, in 6 hours, B and D fill:
6 x[1/12] = 6/12=1/2
Pipe B and D together fill 1/2 of the tank in 6 hours.
The correct answer is option (2).

Question_Text:
Two inlet pipes A and B working together for 4 hours fill 72 units of water
in a tank having capacity 160 units. If A alone can fill the tank in 20 hours,
the time taken by B alone to fill the tank is
Solution:
Tank capacity = 160 units
Pipes A and B together fill 72 units in 4 hours
Pipe A alone fills the tank in 20 hours
Formula used:
Rate of filling = Work done / Time
Rate of A + Rate of B = Combined rate
Time taken = Tank capacity / Rate
Calculation:
Rate of A = Tank capacity / Time taken by A
Rate of A = 160 / 20 = 8 units/hour
Rate of A + Rate of B = Combined rate
Combined rate = Total water filled / Time
Combined rate = 72 / 4 = 18 units/hour
Rate of B = Combined rate - Rate of A
Rate of B = 18 - 8 = 10 units/hour
Time taken by B = Tank capacity / Rate of B
Time taken by B = 160 / 10 = 16 hours

Question_Text:
A cistern has an inlet pipe and an outlet pipe. Inlet pipe can fill three-fourth
of the cistern in 24 minutes while outlet pipe can empty the one-third filled
cistern in 16 minutes. If both the pipes are opened together, then the
cistern will be completely filled in-
Solution:
Inlet pipe can fill three-fourths of the cistern in 24 minutes.
Outlet pipe can empty one-third of the cistern in 16 minutes.
Calculations:
Rate of the inlet pipe = (3/4) cistern / 24 minutes = 3 / (4 x 24) = 1 / 32
cistern per minute.
Rate of the outlet pipe = (1/3) cistern / 16 minutes = 1 / (3 x 16) = 1/48
cistern per minute.
When both pipes are opened together, the combined rate is:
Combined rate = Rate of inlet pipe - Rate of outlet pipe = 1/32 - 1/48
To subtract, find the LCM of 32 and 48, which is 96:
1/32 = 3/96, and 1/48 = 2/96, so combined rate = (3/96) - (2/96) = 1/96 cistern per minute.
Thus, the cistern will be filled in 96 minutes

Question_Text:
A cistern is connected to two inlet pipes, A and B, and one outlet pipe, C.
Pipe A can fill the cistern in 16 hours, and Pipe B can fill it in 12 hours. Pipe
C can drain the entire cistern in 20 hours. If all three pipes are opened at
the same time, how long will it take to completely fill the cistern?
Solution:
Given:

Pipe A can fill the cistern in 16 hours

Pipe B can fill the cistern in 12 hours

Pipe C can drain the cistern in 20 hours

Calculation :-
Let total work be 240 units (LCM of 16, 12, and 20).
Capacity of Pipe A = 240 / 16 = 15 units/hour
Capacity of Pipe B = 240 / 12 = 20 units/hour
Capacity of Pipe C = 240 / 20 = 12 units/hour (since it empties, it's -12)
Net capacity when all three pipes are open = 15 + 20 - 12 = 23 units/hour
10 hours
23
Time to fill the tank = 240 / 23 ~ 10
10
23
Final Answer: 10 hours

Question_Text: A and B take 12 days to complete a given task. B and C together complete the same task in 10 days, while C and A take 20 days to finish the same task. If all of them undertake the task at Rs 700, find the share of C.
Solution:
Combined work of A and B in one day = 1/12

Combined work of B and C in one day = 1/10

Combined work of A and C in one day = 1/20

Adding these,

⇒ 1/A + 1/B + 1/B + 1/C + 1/A + 1/C = 1/12 + 1/10 + 1/20

⇒ (5 + 6 + 3)/60 = 7/30

⇒ 2(1/A + 1/B + 1/C) = 7/30

⇒ (1/A + 1/B + 1/C) = 7/60

If we subtract A and B combined work we get,

1/C = 7/60 - 1/12 = 2/60

Ratio of work done by C = 2/60 ÷ 7/60 = 2/7

Share of C = 700 × 2/7 = Rs 200

Question_Text: A, B and C are three book binders. A takes 10 minutes, B takes 12 minutes and C takes 15 minutes to bind a book. If they work each day for 12 hours, then on an average, a person can bind how many books per day?
Solution:
A takes 10 min to bind 1 book 

∴ In 60 min A binds = 60/10 = 6 books

B takes 12 min to bind 1 book

∴ In 60 min B binds = 60/12 = 5 books

C takes 15 min to bind 1 book 

∴ In 60 min C bind = 60/15 = 4 book

Number of books bound by them in 1 hour = 6 + 5 + 4 = 15

Total number of books bound by them in 12 hours = 15 × 12 = 180

∴ Required average = 180/3 = 60 books

Question_Text: A man takes 12 days to complete a work by working for 8 hours a day while a woman completes the same work in 8 days by working 10 hours a day. In how many days will both of them complete the work by working together for 8 hours a day?
Solution:
A man can complete a work in 12 days by working 8 hours a day

A woman can complete the same work in 8 days by working 10 hours a day

Numbers of hours taken by the man to complete the work = 12 × 8 = 96

Work done in an hour by the man = 1/96

Number of hours taken by woman to complete the work = 8 × 10 = 80

Work done in an hour by the woman = 1/80

Work done by both of them in one hour = (1/96) + (1/80) = 11/480

work done by them in 8 hours = 8 × (11/480) = 11/60

So, Work will be completed in 60/11 days

Question_Text: The amount of job that Amal, Sunil and Kamal can individually do in a day, are in harmonic progression. Kamal takes twice as much time as Amal to do the same amount of job. If Amal and Sunil work for ...
Solution:
Let us assume the efficiencies of Amal, Sunil, and
Kamal are a, s, and k, respectively.

Given that they are in H.P.
Also, given that Kamal takes twice as much time as
Amal to do the same amount of job
=> a = 2k
Given that when Amal and Sunil work for 4 days and
9 days, respectively, Kamal needs to work for 16
days to finish the remaining job.

=> If W is the total work => 4a + 9s + 16k = W.
from (1)2/s =1/a+2/a =>a=3/2s and k = 3/4s
=> 4(3s/2)+9s+16(3s/4) = W
=> 6s+9s+12s = W
=>27s = W
=>s=W/27
Sunil will take 27 days to finish the work when working alone

Question_Text: Three men and eight machines can finish a job in half the time taken by three machines and eight men to finish the same job. If two machines can finish the job in 13 days, then how many men can finish the job in 13 days?
Solution:
Consider the work done by a man in a day = a, and that by a machine = b 
Since three men and eight machines can finish a job in half the time taken by three machines and eight men to finish the same job, the efficiency will be doubled.

=>3a+8b = 2(3b+8a)
=>13a=2b
Hence work done by 13 men in a day=work done by 2 machines in a day.
=> If two machines can finish the job in 13 days, then the same work will be done by 13 men in 13 days.
Hence the required number of men = 13

Question_Text:
Humans and robots can both perform a job but
at different efficiencies. Fifteen humans and
five robots working together take thirty days to
finish the job, whereas five humans and fifteen
robots working together take sixty days to
finish it. How many days will fifteen humans
working together (without any robot) take to
finish it?
Solution:
Let the efficiency of humans be 'h' and the efficiency of robots be 'r'.
 In the first case, 
 Total work = (15h + 5r) * 30......(i) 
In the second case,
 Total work = (5h + 15r) * 60......(ii) 
On equation (i) and (ii), we get
(15h+15r)*30 = (5h+15r)*60
or,15h+15r = 10h+30r
or,5h=25r
or,h=5r
Total work =(15h+5r)*30 = (15h+h)*30 = 480h
Time taken by 15 humans = 480h/15h days = 32 days.

Question_Text:
If 2 men or 3 women or 4 boys can do a piece of work in 52 days, then
the same piece of work will be done by 1 man, 1 woman and 1 boy in:
Solution:
Work done by 2 men = 3 women = 4 boys
1 man = 2 boys
1 woman = 4/3 boys
Thus,
Boys × days = 4 × 52 boys × days
Again,
1 man + 1 women + 1 boys,
=2+4/3+1
=13/3 boys
Using work equivalent method,
boys × day = BOYS × DAYS
4×52=13/3 * x(let)

x = 48 days

Question_Text:
38. Two typist of varying skills can do a job in 6 minutes if they
work together. If the first typist typed alone for 4 minutes and
then the second typist typed alone for 6 minutes, they would be
left with 1/5 of the whole work. How many minutes would it take 
the slower typist to complete the typing job working alone ?
Solution:
Working efficiency of both typist together,
= 100/6 = 16.66% per minute

Now, let work efficiency of first typist be x and then second typist will be (16.66 - x)
First typist typed alone for 4 minutes and second typed alone for 6 minutes and they left with 1/5 (i.e 20%) of job, means they have completed 80% job
Now,
First Typist typed in 4 minute + Second typed in 6 minutes = 80%
4 × x + 6 × (16.66 - x) = 80%
4x + 100% - 6x = 80%
x = 10%
First Typist typed 10% per minutes. Then second typed (16.66 - 10) = 6.66% per minute
Then, Second typist complete the whole job in 100/6.66 = 15.01 = 15 minutes.

Question_Text: Ram can do the work in 20 days. Ram and Shyam together can do the same work in 15 days. If they are paid Rs.400 for that work, what is the share of Shyam (in Rs.).
Solution:
Ram = 20 days

Ram + shyam = 15 days

Efficiency (LCM of ram & shyam) = 60

Ram efficiency = 60 /20  3 unit/day

Ram + Shyam efficiency = 60 / 15  4 unit/day

Shyam alone = 4- 3  1 unit/day

Shyam share = 1/4 * 400  Rs. 100

Question_Text: Rama can do a piece of work in 10 days and Rami alone can do it in 5 days. Rama and Rami undertook to do it for Rs.400. With the help of their neighbour Snooty, they finished it in 2 days. The share of Snooty out of the remuneration is
Solution:
(Rama + Rami + Snooty)'s one day's work = 1/10 + 1/5 + 1/X.
(Rama + Rami + Snooty)'s two day's work = 2 x (1/10 + 1/5 + 1/X).
{because they need 2 days to do the job)
=> 2 [ 1/10 + 1/5 + 1/X ] = 1 = On solving we get, X = 5 days.
This means that Snooty can do the whole work alone in 5 days.
=> In one day, he does 1/5 of the work.
=>In two days, he does (2 x 1/5) of the work.
=> Snooty's share = 1/5 x 2 x 400 = Rs.160.

Question_Text: A alone can do a piece of work in 6 days and B alone in 8 days. A and B undertook to do it for Rs. 3200. With the help of C, they completed the work in 3 days. How much is to be paid to C?
Solution:
Let the total work done be 24x (as 24 is the LCM of 6 & 8)

Part of work done by A in a day = 24x/6 = 4x

Part of work done by B in a day = 24x/8 = 3x

Part of work done by A, B and C in a day = 24x/3 = 8x

Work done by C in a day = 8x - 4x - 3x = x

Work done by C in 3 days = 3x

For 24x work amount to be paid = Rs. 3200

Amount paid to C = (3200/24x) x 3x

= Amount paid to C = 400

:. C is paid Rs. 400

Question_Text: The labourers A, B, C were given a contract of Rs. 750 for doing a certain piece of work. All the three together can finish the work in 8 days. A and C together can do it in 12 days while A and B together can do it in 13(1/3)days. The money will be divided in the ratio.
Solution:
A+B+C  = 8 --------------10
A+C    = 12 ------------- 120 [LCM of 8,12,40/3]
A+B    =  40/3 ------------9     
13 1/3 = 40/3

As we know, money divided in their efficiency ratio.
A + B + C = 15,
 A + C = 10 
 A + B = 9
Efficiency of B = 15 - 10 = 5
Efficiency of A = 9 - 5 = 4
Efficiency of C = 10 - 4 = 6
The money divided among A, B, and C in the ratio = 4 : 5 : 6

Question_Text: Sandy and Mandy do (8/13)th part of the work and the rest of the work was completed by Andy. If Sandy, Mandy and Andy take the same work for Rs 2600, then what is the share (in Rs) of Andy?
Solution:
Formula used : W = E xT 

Where, W = Work, E = Efficiency, and T = Time

Calculation : 

Let the amount of total work be “a” 

Work done by Sandy and Mandy = 8a/13

Work done by Andy = a - 8a/13 = 5a/13

Total amount of money taken by the 3 people = Rs. 2600

Andy's share = 2600 x [(5a/13)/a]

 Andy's share = Rs. 1000

Question_Text: 12 Men and 6 women can do a piece of work in 14 days, while 8 men and 9 women can do the work in 16 days. if a man gets Rs 54 per days, what should be the wage of a woman per day?
Solution:
Let a man's and a woman's one day work be denoted by M and W, respectively.

12M + 6W=  1/14   and 8M + 9W = 1/16

Solving the two equations, we get M = 1/224  and W = 1/336

Now, M/W = 3/2

Woman's Wage = 2/3 * man's wage 
 
                          =2/3 x  54 = Rs 36.

Question_Text: A and B complete a task in 12 days and 16 days respectively. They work together to finish the task and earn ₹5600. How should the wages be divided between A and B?
Solution:
Total work = LCM(12, 16) = 48 unit
Efficiency of A = 48/12=4 units/day
Efficiency of B = 48/16=3 units/day
Ratio of efficiencies = 4:3
A's share = 4/7×5600=₹3200
B's share = ₹2400

Question_Text: A, B, and C are hired to complete a task for ₹9000. A can complete the task in 15 days, B in 20 days, and C in 30 days. How much will each person earn if they work together to complete the task?
Solution:
Total work = LCM(15, 20, 30) = 60 units
efficiency  of A = 60/15=4  , efficiency of B = 60/20=3, efficiency of C = 60/30=2
Wages are divided in the ratio 4:3:2
A's share = 4/9×9000=₹4000
B's share =3/9 x 9000= 3000
C's share = 2/9 x9000= 2000

Question_Text: A and B are paid ₹4800 to complete a task. A works for 6 days and B works for 8 days to complete it. If A’s efficiency is twice that of B, what are their individual earnings?
Solution:
Let B’s efficiency = x. Then, A’s efficiency = 2x
Work done by A = 6×2x=12x
Work done by B = 8×x=8x
Ratio of work = 12x:8x=3:2 
A’s share = 3/5×4800=₹2880
B’s share = ₹1920

Question_Text: A, B, and C earn ₹8400 for a task. A and B together can complete the task in 8 days, B and C together in 12 days, and A and C together in 10 days. How much will A earn?
Solution:
Total work = LCM(8, 12, 10) = 120 units
Efficiency of A + B = 120/8=15
Efifciency of  B + C = 120/12=10
Efficiency of  A + C = 120/10=12.
So Efficiency of  A+B+C=37/2=18.5
Ratio = 8.5:6.5:3.5
A’s share = 8.5/18.5×8400=₹3856.76

Question_Text: Ram and Shyam undertake a piece of work for Rs 300. Ram can do it in 20 days and Shyam can do it in 60 days. With the help of Radha, they finish it in 10 days. How much should Radha be paid for her contribution?
Solution:
Ram alone takes 20 days and Shyam alone takes 60 days to finish the work.
All together can finish in 10 days.
Let the total work done is LCM(10, 20, 60) = 60
Ram’s efficiency = 60/20 = 3
Shyam’s efficiency = 60/60 = 1
Combined Efficiency = 60/10= 6
Radha’s efficiency = 6 – 3 -1 = 2

efficiency ratio = 3:1:2

therefore radha’s money = (2/6)*300=100 rs

Question_Text: A, B and C took a job on contract for Rs. 6300. Only A and B worked for the first 6 days and only C worked for the next 4. If C alone can do the task in 10 days, how much is his share in the payment?
Solution:
C can complete the entire job in 10 days.

C's work rate is 1/10​ of the job per day.

C worked for 4 days

Work done by C = 4 days ×1/10​ of the job per day = 4/10=2/5​ of the job.

Calculate C's share of the payment:

Total payment for the job is Rs. 6300.

C's share = 2/5​ of Rs. 6300 = 2/5×6300.

Calculate the amount:

C′s share=2/5​×6300=2520

Question_Text: A, B and C together earn Rs. 640 for 1 day’s work, A and B earn Rs. 1440 for 4 days’ work, B and C also earn Rs. 1440 for 3 days work. How much money (in rupees) would B earn for a day’s work?

Mayank can do a piece of work in 3 days while Sanjay can do the same work in 4 days. The wage for the full work is Rs. 350. If they both work together to complete the work then find the earnings of Sanjay.

Question_Text: Excluding stoppages, the speed of a bus is 54 kmph and including stoppages, it is 45 kmph. For how many minutes does the bus stop per hour?
Solution:
Due to stoppages, it covers 9 km less.

Question_Text: The ratio between the speeds of two trains is 7 : 8. If the second train runs 400 km in 4 hours, then the speed of the first train is:

 x = 100/8 = 12.5 

Speed of first train = (7 x 12.5) km/hr = 87.5 km/hr.

35 km/hr

Question_Text: A person crosses a 600 m long street in 5 minutes. What is his speed in km per hour?

Speed = Distance / Time

Calculation:

 Speed in km per hour is 7.2 km/hr.

Question_Text: A train covers a distance of 360 km at a certain speed. If its speed had been 20 km/h more, it would have taken 1 hour less. What is the original speed of the train?

Then time taken =  360/X hours.

360/x – 360/(x + 20) = 1
Solve:
(360(x + 20) - 360x)/(x(x + 20)) = 1
(360-20)/(x(x + 20)) = 1
7200 = x(x + 20)
x2 + 20x - 7200 = 0
Solving the quadratic:
x = 75

Question_Text: A man travels from town A to B at 40 km/h and returns at 60 km/h. What is his average speed for the entire journey?
Solution:
Average speed for a round trip when speeds are different:
Average Speed = 2xy/(x + y) 
                           = (2*40*60*)/(40 + 60} 
                           = 4800/100
                           = 48 km/h

Question_Text: A cyclist travels 50 km at a certain speed. Due to a puncture, his speed reduces by 5 km/h for the next 50 km. If the entire journey takes 9 hours, what was his original speed?
Solution:
Let original speed = X km/h
Then reduced speed = X-5 km/h
Time = 50/X + 50/(X-5) = 9
50(X-5) + 50X = 9(X(X-5))
50X-250 + 50X = 9(X2 – 5X)
100X-250 = 9X2 – 45X
9x2 - 145x + 250 = 0
X = 14km/hr

Question_Text: A man decided to cover a distance of 6 km in 84 minutes. He decided to cover two-thirds of the distance at 4 km/hr and the remaining at some different speed. Find the speed after the two-thirds distance has been covered.
Solution: 4 km distance was covered at 4 km/hr.  Time taken to cover 4 km = 4 km / 4 km / hr = 1 hr = 60 minutes => Time left = 84 - 60 = 24 minutes Now, the man has to cover the remaining 2 km in 24 minutes or 24 / 60 = 0.4 hours => Speed required for remaining 2 km = 2 km / 0.4 hr = 5 km / hr

Question_Text: The distance between two cities A and B is 80 km. A motorcycle rider starts from A towards B at 7 am at a speed of 10 km/hr. Another motorcyclist starts from B towards A at 8 am at a speed of 25 km/hr. At what time will they cross each other?
Solution:
In one hour, the earlier rider covers a distance of 10 km.

The distance between the two = 80 – 10 = 70 km.

Hence, the two riders approach each other with a relative speed of 10 + 25 = 35 kmph.

The time taken = 70/35 = 2 hrs. Therefore, they meet each other at (8 + 2) = 10 am.

Question_Text: Two trains start at the same time from two stations and proceed towards each other at the rate of 20 km/hr and 25 km/hr respectively. When they meet, it is found that one train has traveled 80 km more than the other. Find the distance between the two stations.
Solution:
In one hour, one train travels 5 km more than the other. The trains meet in 80/5 = 16 hours.

Therefore, the distance = (20 + 25) x 16 = 720 km.

Question_Text: Two trains start at the same time from Aligarh and Delhi and proceed towards each other at the rate of 16 km/hr and 21 km/hr respectively. When they meet, it is found that one train has traveled 60 km more than the other. The distance between the two stations is
Solution:
Both the trains are coming closer to each other by (21 – 16), i.e., 5 km every hour.

They would meet after 60/5 = 12 hrs. Hence, the distance between the 2 stations = (21 + 16) x 12 = 37 x 12 = 444 km

Question_Text:
A security guard starts chasing a robber. When the robber takes 12
steps, the guard takes 9 steps. Additionally, 4 steps of the guard
are equal in distance to 5 steps of the robber. What is the ratio of
the speeds of the guard and the robber?
Solution:
Robber takes 12 steps while the guard takes 9 steps in the same time.

This means the step frequency ratio steps per unit time is:

Guard Steps: Robber Steps = 9 : 12 = 3 : 4

4 steps of the guard = 5 steps of the robber in distance.

Thus, the step length ratio is:

Guard Step Length: Robber Step Length = 5:4

Speed is determined by step frequency x step length.

Let:

Guard's step frequency = 33 steps/sec.
Robber's step frequency = 44 steps/sec.

Guard's step length = 55 units.

Robber's step length = 44 units.

Guard's Speed = 3 x 5 = 15 units/sec.

Robber's Speed = 4 x 4=16 units/sec.

Speed Ratio = Guard's Speed: Robber's Speed = 15 : 16

Thus, the ratio of the speeds of the guard and the robber is 15 : 16.

Question_Text: The ratio between the speeds of two trains is 7: 8: If the second train runs 400 kms in 4 hours, then the speed of first train is:
Solution: Given ratio = 7:8, Speed of the second train = 100 km/h Speed of the first train = (100 × 7) / 8 ⇒ Speed of the first train = 700 / 8 ⇒ Speed of the first train = 87.5 km/h The speed of the first train is 87.5 km/h.

Question_Text: A rocket is launched at intervals of 11.5 seconds, moving in the same direction as a train traveling at an unknown speed. The speed of sound is 330 m/s. If a person seated inside the train hears the sound of the rocket after 11 seconds, determine the speed of the train.
Moving at 50 kmph, a person reaches his office 10 min late. Next day, he increases his speed and moves at 60 kmph and reaches his office 5 min early. What is the distance from his home to his office?
Solution:
We can observe that difference in timings on both days is 15 min (and not 5 min, as one day he is late and on the other day he is early)
Let the required distance = D km. As time taken at the speed of 50 kmph is more than time taken at 60 kmph, so equation can be formed as D/50-D/60=15/60.Solving this equation, we get the answer as 75 km.

Question_Text: A person goes from A to B at the speed of 40 kmph and comes back at the speed of 60 kmph. What is his average speed for the whole journey?
Solution:
Since the distance traveled on both sides is the same, we can use the formula of harmonic mean of speeds.
Average Speed: 2xy/(x+y) where, x is the speed while going from A to B and y is the speed while coming back.
So using this formula, we get the answer as 48 kmph.

Question_Text: A train 125 m long passes a man, running at 5 km/hr in the same direction in which the train is going, in 10 seconds. The speed of the train is
Solution:
Let the speed of the train be x km/hr. Then, relative speed = (x - 5) km/hr.

 x - 5 = 45          x = 50 km/hr.

Question_Text: Two trains running in opposite directions cross a man standing on the platform in 27 seconds and 17 seconds respectively and they cross each other in 23 seconds. The ratio of their speeds is:
Solution:

Then, length of the first train = 27x metres,

and length of the second train = 17y metres.         27x + 17y/x+y = 23 ,..x/y = 3/2

Question_Text: A train 360 m long is running at a speed of 45 km/hr. In what time will it pass a bridge 140 m long?
A 270 metres long train running at the speed of 120 kmph crosses another train running in opposite direction at the speed of 80 kmph in 9 seconds. What is the length of the other train?
Solution:
Let length of the train be x m
Length of first train = 270 m
Speed of the two trains is 120 km/hr and 80 km/h
Relative speed, if opposite direction = 120 + 80 = 200 * 5/18  =500/9 m/sec

As we know,
Speed = distance/time
500/9 = (270 +x)/9
 x = 500 – 270
X = 230

Question_Text: A flight from Srinagar to Trivandrum has an average speed of 400 km/hr without any stoppage. The average speed decreases to 320 km/hr when there are stoppages. Find the stoppage time per hour of the flight?
Solution:
Minutes of stops per hour = [(Faster speed - Slower speed)/Faster speed] x 60
Difference in speed = 400−320=80 km/hr.
Stoppage time per hour = 80/400=1/5 hours. 
Stoppage time per hour = 1/5×60=12 minutes.

Question_Text: Without any stoppage, a person travels a certain distance at an average speed of 42 km/h, and with stoppages, he covers the same distance at an average speed of 28 km/h. How many minutes per hour does he stop
Solution:
Minutes of stops per hour = [(Faster speed - Slower speed)/Faster speed] x 60
Let the total distance to be covered is 84 kms.Time taken to cover the distance without stoppage = 84/42 hrs = 2 hrsTime taken to cover the distance with stoppage = 84/28 = 3 hrs.Thus, he takes 60 minutes to cover the same distance with stoppage.Therefore, in 1 hour he stops for 20 minutes.

Question_Text: A train 110 metres long is running with a speed of 60 kmph. In what time will it pass a man who is running at 6 kmph in the direction opposite to that in which the train is going?
Solution:
Relative speed = 60 + 6 = 66 km/hr                        

Distance = speed * time 

110 = 66 * 5/18 * t

T = 6 sec

Solution:
Speed in m/s=Speed in km/h×1000/3600 m/s
​=36×5/18=10 m/s
2: Determine the Length of the Train

L+400=650

Question_Text: Two  train  start at  the  same time   from A &B   and proceed towards  B  and A  at 36km/hr  and 42km/hr respectively . when they  meet, it is found   that one train   has  moved 48km more than the other . what is the distance  between  A  and  B ?

Two trains running in opposite directions on parallel tracks, at speeds of 33 km/hr and 39 km / hr ,take 23 seconds to cross each other. If the length of one train is 250 m, then the length of the other train is:
Solution:
Let the length of the second train be x cm.

Speed of the second train = 39 km/h

Time taken to cross each other = 23 sec

Speed = Distance/Time

 (33 + 39) x 5/18 = (250+x)/23

210m

Question_Text: Two stations A and B are 110 km apart on a straight line. One train starts from A at 7 a.m. and travels towards B at 20 kmph. Another train starts from B at 8 a.m. and travels towards A at a speed of 25 kmph. At what time will they meet?

45X=135

Question_Text: A train starts at 11:00 am from point A towards point B at 36 km/h while another train starts at 1:00 pm from point B  towards point A at 44 km/h. They cover a distance of 712 km till the meeting. At what time will they meet each other?
Solution:
Distance travelled by train which starts from point a from 11 to 1 pm =  36 * 2 = 72 km
Distance left = 712 – 72 -- > 640 km
Relative speed = 36 + 44-- > 80 km/hr
Time = 640/80 -- > 8 hr 

T = 9:00 

or
Let both trains meet each other after t hours from 11 am.
Distance = Speed x Time
36 x t + 44 (t - 2) =712
36t + 44t-88 = 712
80t=712 +88 
T = 10 hours
i.e.= 9:00 pm

Question_Text: A 720m long train takes 96 seconds more to cross a platform than it takes to cross a pole at the same speed. Given that the length of platform is twice the length of train. What is the speed of train in km/h?
Solution:
The length of the platform is twice the length of the train. 

Length of platform = 2×720=1440m

Time to cross the pole: tp=720/v

Time to cross the platform: tpt=720+1440/v=2160/v

The train takes 96s more to cross the platform than the pole: tpl=tp+96

 the speed, 2160/v=720/v+96

2160 – 720 = 96v

V = 1440/96 --- > 15 m/s

Convert into km/hr  15 * 18/5  54 km/hr

Solution:
Let right time for the train to cover its journey (in minutes) be x min,
Distance = Speed x Time
Distance is same, then
84 * (x+25)/60= 98 * (x+10)/60
6 (x + 25) = 7 (x + 10)
6x + 150 = 7x + 70
x = 150 – 70  
X = 80 min

Question_Text: A boat can travel at a speed of 13 km/hr in still water. If the speed of the stream is 4 km/hr, find the time taken by the boat to go 68 km downstream
Solution:
Speed downstream = (13 + 4) km/hr = 17 km/hr.
Time taken to travel 68 km downstream =68/17 hrs = 4 hrs.

Question_Text: A boat running downstream covers a distance of 24 km in 3 hours, while covering the same distance upstream, it takes 6 hours. What is the speed of the current?
Solution: The downstream speed = 24/3 = 8 km/hrThe upstream speed = 24/6 = 4 km/hrThe speed of the current = (8-4)/2 = 4/2 = 2km/hr

Question_Text: Speed of the boat in still water is 15 km/hr and the speed of the current is 7 km/hr. Find the total time taken by a man rowing to a place at a distance of 88 km and back.
Solution: The downstream speed is 15 + 7 = 22 km/hr, and The upstream speed = 15 - 7 = 8 km/hr.                    The total time taken = (88/22) + (88/8) = 4+11 = 15hours

Question_Text: An escalator having 60 steps is moving up at the speed of 2 steps/second. Aakash has to go to the first floor and come back on this escalator. Calculate the time taken by Akash if his speed on stationary escalator is 3 steps/second.
Solution:
Explanation :Speed of Akas while going upstairs = 3 + 2 = 5 s/s.
Time take to go up = 60/5 = 12 seconds.
Speed of Akas while going downstairs = 3 - 2 = 1 s/s.
Time take to come down = 60/1 = 60 seconds.
=Total time taken by Akash = 12 + 60 = 72 seconds.
Hence, 72.

Question_Text: Bobby is going up the escalator. It takes Bobby 80 seconds to walk up the escalator, which is moving upwards and 120 seconds to walk up the escalator, which is moving downwards. Calculate the time (in secs) taken by Bobby to climb the escalator which is stationary
Solution:
Let Bobby's speed be "a" steps per second and 
The escalator's speed be "x“ steps per second. 
When the escalator is moving up, no. of steps
N = 80a + 80x (Since Bobby is moving upwards, 80x will be added)
When the escalator is moving down, no. of steps 
N = 120a - 120x (Since Bobby is moving upwards, 120x will be subtracted)
By equating the number of steps, 80a + 80x = 120a - 120x.
a = 5x
= N = 80a + 80x = 80a + 16a = 96a..
 Time taken when the escalator is stationary = 96a/a = 96 seconds.
Hence, 96

Question_Text: P and Q walk up a moving escalator at constant speeds. For every 5 steps that P takes, Q takes 3 steps. How many steps would each have to climb when the escalator is switched off, given that P takes 50 and Q takes 40 steps to climb up the moving escalator, respectively?
Solution:
Both the person and the escalator are moving in the same direction.
 In this case, the relative speed would be Speed of (Man + Stairs).We don't know the speed of the escalator, so assume that to be e. Let the speed of P be 5a steps/sec and Q's is 3a steps/sec.
P is walking 50 steps and he does it in 50/5a = 10/secs., but in this 10/a secs, even the escalator must have moved with speed "e".
 The length moved by it would be 10e/a.
So, we can say the total length is 50 + 10e/a (steps moved by P and the escalator helps P in reaching the top). 
Similarly, for Q we can write 40 + 40e/3a
Both are moving on the same escalator, 
hence the total number of steps should be same.50 + 10e/a = 40 + 40e/3a
So, e/a = 3
So total length is 50 + 10e/a = 80
Topic: Problems on Boats  and   streams  , Escalator

Question_Text: A speedboat runs 6 km upstream in a river and comes back to the starting point in 33 minutes. The stream of the river is running at 2 km/hr. What is the speed of speedboat in still water?
Solution:
Total time = d / (x - s) + d / (x + s)
Let the speed of the speedboat in still water be x km/h.Then, speed downstream = (x + 2) km/h, speed upstream = (x - 2) km/h.Since it goes 6 km upstream and comes back in 33 minutes,we have 6/(x+2) + 6/(x-2) = 33/60 = 11/20-->11x² - 240x - 44 = 011x² - 242x + 2x - 44 = 0-- >(x - 22)(11x + 2) = 0x = 22. Therefore, the required speed = 22 km/h.
Topic: Problems on Boats  and   streams  , Escalator

Question_Text: A boat can covers a certain distance in upstream and same distance in downstream in total of 7 hours 48 minutes, If upstream speed of the boat is 62.5% of downstream speed of the boat and speed of the stream is 3 km/hr, what is the total distance covered by the boat?

So, x = 2
So, upstream speed is 10 and downstream speed is 16

So, D/16 + D /10 = 7 (48/60) = 39/5Or, 13D/80 = 39/5Or, D = 48 km

Question_Text: Shivam is climbing on a moving escalator that is going up and takes 30 steps to reach the top. Atharva on the other hand is coming down on the same escalator. For every5 steps that Atharva takes, Shivam takes only 3 steps. Both of them take the same amount of time to reach the other end. What is the difference in the number of stepsthat both of them had taken when they crossed each other?
Solution:
Since both of them take the same time for the same distance, their effective speed is the same.
=> 5s -  x = 3s + x
=>x = S
Speed of Shivam: Speed of escalator = 3s: s = 3: 1
When Shivam takes 30 steps, the escalator takes 10 steps.
Total number of steps = 30 + 10 = 40 steps.
Both of them would have covered 20 steps when they crossed each other.
Shivam going up would have taken 15 steps, whereas the escalator would have taken 5 steps for him.
Atharva coming down would have taken 25 steps, out of which the escalator would have nullified the movement of 5 steps for him.
Difference in the number of steps = 25 - 15 = 10 steps.
Topic: Problems on Boats  and   streams  , Escalator

Question_Text: Anand takes 90 secs to move up an escalator which is moving downward and hetakes 30 secs to move down the same escalator. How much time (in seconds)will he take to go up or down, when the escalator is switched off?
Solution:
Take the length of the stairs LCM(90, 30) = 90
Time taken when going upstream is 90 seconds, 
so we can say M - E = 90/90 = 1 , M + E = 90/30 = 3
So, speed of Man = 4/2 = 2Time taken is 90/2 = 45 sec
Alternately,
When moving upstream, speed is M + E
 When the escalator is stopped, is M 
And when moving upstream, speed is M–E 
Speed is in AP, so time will be in HP, since they are inversely proportional.
So, the time taken would be – 
2*90*30/(90+30) = 60 *90/120 = 45 secs.
Topic: Problems on Boats  and   streams  , Escalator

Question_Text: In the downstream, two steamers A and B start simultaneously from the point P, but the steamer B reaches point Q, 2 hours before the steamer A reaches the same point. If the distance between point P and Q is 120 km and the speed of steamer B in upstream is 3 km per hour more than that of steamer B in upstream and the speed of stream is 2 km per hour, then find the sum of the speed of steamer A in still water and that of steamer B in still water?
Solution:
Let the speed of steamer A in still water = a km per hour and the speed of steamer B in still water = b
km per hour
The speed of stream = 2 km per hour
Then, according to the question, (b – 2) – (a – 2) = b – a = 3
In downstream, the speed of steamer A = a + 2 = b – 3 + 2 = b – 1 km per hour
The speed of steamer B = b + 2 km per hour
Then, according to the question,
120 – 120 = 2
b – 1 b + 2
By solving, b = 13 km per hour
Therefore, the speed of steamer A in still water = 13 – 3 = 10 km per hour
The required sum = 10 + 13 = 23 km per hour
Topic: Problems on Boats  and   streams  , Escalator

Question_Text: Two boats A and B start from two points P and Q respectively in a river along the flow of river. Boat A has speed 10 kmph and goes downstream to reach Q while B has speed 12 kmph and goes upstream to reach P. If ratio of time A and B took is 5:6, find the ratio of time taken by A and B for the return trip.
Solution:
Let the stream speed be r kmph.
Since the distance between P and Q is constant, we have the below equation according to the given
information
(12–r)/(10 + r) = 5/6
r = 2
In return trip, speed of A = 10 – 2 = 8 kmph
Speed of B = 12 + 2 = 14 kmph
Ratio of time taken by A to B = 14 : 8 = 7 : 4
Hence, option 2 is correct.
Topic: Problems on Boats  and   streams  , Escalator

Question_Text: In a 50 m race, A can give a start of 5 m to B and a start of 14 m to C. In the same race, how much start can B give to C ?
Solution:
At the same time,
 A covers 50 m, B covers (50 – 5) = 45 m, and C covers (50 – 14) = 36 m.
 If the race is between B and C only, applying the unitary method, 
when B runs 45 m, C runs 36 m. 
Hence, when B runs 50 m, C runs (36/45 × 50 = 40) 
This means B gives C a 10 m start.

Question_Text: A and B take part in a 100 m race. A gives B a start of 10 m and still beats B by 5 seconds. If A's speed is 2.5 m/s, find B's speed.
Solution:
Time taken by A to cover 100 m = 100/2.5 = 40 seconds 
A gives B a start of 10 m. 
Hence, B covers only 90 m. 
A beats B by 5 seconds. Hence, time taken by B to cover 90 m = 40+5 = 45 seconds
 B covers 90 m in 45 seconds. 
B's speed = 90/45 = 2 m/s

Question_Text: In a 5000-metre race, if runner A runs at a speed of 12 metres per second and runner B runs at a speed of 15 metres per second, how many seconds will it take for runner B to finish the race if runner A finishes the race in 20 minutes?
Solution:
let's convert the time it takes for runner A to finish the race from minutes to seconds.
Runner A finishes the race in 20 minutes, which is equivalent to:
20 minutes * 60 seconds/minute = 1200 seconds
Now, we can calculate how far runner A would have run in 1200 seconds at a speed of 12 meters per second:
Distance = Speed × Time
Distance = 12 m/s × 1200 s = 14400 meters
So, runner A covers a distance of 14400 meters in 1200 seconds.
Now, we need to find out how long it will take runner B, who runs at a speed of 15 meters per second, to cover the same distance (14400 meters). We can use the formula:
Time = Distance / Speed
Time = 14400 meters / 15 m/s = 960 seconds
Therefore, it will take runner B 960 seconds to finish the race, which is 16 minutes.

⇒80(t+5)=11(7t+50)⇒(80t−77t)=(550−400)⇒3t=150⇒t=50

=8m/sec
∴B's speed=385/55m/sec

Question_Text: In a linear race of 500 m, A beats B by 50 m, and in a race of 600 m, B beats C by 60 m. By how many metres will A beat C in a race of 400 m?

In a mile race, Akshay can be given a start of 128 m by Bhairav. If Bhairav can give Chinmay a start of 4 m in a 100 m dash, then who out of Akshay and Chinmay will win a race of one and half miles, and what will be the final lead given by the winner to the loser? One mile is 1,600 m
Solution:
In a mile race, Akshay can be given a start of 128 m by Bhairav. This means that Bhairav can afford to start after Akshay has travelled 128 m and still complete one mile with him. In other words, Bhairav can travel one mile, i.e. 1,600 m in the same time as Akshay can travel (1600 – 128) = 1,472 m. Hence, the ratio of the speeds of Bhairav and Akshay = Ratio of the distances travelled by them in the same time = 1600/1472 = 25 : 23.

Bhairav can give Chinmay a start of 4 miles. This means that in the time Bhairav runs 100 m, Chinmay only runs 96 m. So the ratio of the speeds of Bhairav and Chinmay = 96 : 100 = 25 : 24.

Hence, we have B : A = 25 : 23 and B : C = 25 : 24. So A : B : C = 23 : 25 : 24. This means that in the time Chinmay covers 24 m, Akshay only covers 23 m. In other words, Chinmay is faster than Akshay. So if they race for 1.5 miles = 2,400 m, Chinmay will complete the race first and by this time Akshay would only complete 2,300 m. In other words, Chinmay would beat Akshay by 100 m = 1/16 mile.

Question_Text: In a 1500 m race, if vehicle P gives vehicle Q a start of 200 m, then vehicle P wins the race by 8 sec. Alternatively, if vehicle P gives vehicle Q a start of 400 m, the race ends in a dead heat. How long does vehicle P take to run 1500 m?
In a 10 km race. A, B, and C, each running at uniform speed, get the gold, silver, and bronze medals, respectively. If A beats B by 1 km and B beats C by 1 km, then by how many metres does A beat C?
Solution:
A beats B by 1 km, means A travels 10 km in the same time that B travels 9 km. The ratio of speeds of A and B is 10 : 9. Similarly, the ratio of speeds of B and C is 10 : 9.
A : B = 10 : 9
B : C = 10 : 9
⇒ The ratio of speeds of A : B : C = 100 : 90 : 81
In the same time that A travels 100 m, C travels 81 metres ⇒ In the same time that A travels 10000 m, C would travel 8100 m or A would beat C by 1900 m.

Question_Text: A train approaches a tunnel AB. Inside the tunnel is a cat located at a point that is 3/8 th of the distance AB measured from the entrance A. When the train whistles the cat runs. If the cat moves to the entrance of the tunnel, A, the train catches the cat exactly at the entrance. If the cat moves to the exit, B, the train catches the cat at exactly the exit. Ratio of the speed of train to speed of cat?
Solution:
Explanation:
Let the length of the tunnel be x and distance of the train to entrance A be y. Let the speeds of train and cat be t and c respectively. 
Hence, when the cat runs 3x/8, the train covers y.
 => (3x/8)/c
 => (3x/8)/c = y/t−−− (1) 
When the cat runs 5x/8 to the other end, the train covers x+y 
=>(5x/8)/c = (x+y)/t−−−(2) 
Taking ratio of (1) to (2) 3/5 = y/(x+y)
=> 3x = 2y −−−(3) 
Substituting (3) in (2y/8)/c = y/t 
  => t = 4c Hence the ratio t:c is 4:1....

Question_Text: A and B run a 1 km race. If A gives B a start of 50m, A wins by 14 seconds, and if A gives B a start of 22 seconds, B wins by 20 m. Find the time taken by A to run 1 km.
Solution:
Let the speeds of A and B be a m/s and b m/s respectively. 
Case (I): A gives B a start of 50 m.
 A wins by 14 seconds. 
A runs 1000 m, while B runs only 950 m 
A reached 14 seconds before B. 
Distance travelled by B in 14 seconds = 14b 
Hence, while A ran 1000m, 
B had completed only 950-14b m 
a/b = 1000/(950-14b) 
Case (II): A gives B a start of 22 seconds. 
B wins by 20 meters.
 A started 22 seconds after B started. 
A was 20 meters behind(980 m) when B completed 1000 m.
 Distance covered by B in the first 22 seconds = 22b 
If B had also started at the same time, B would have run (1000-22b) m
 a/b = 980/(1000-2b) 
1000/(950-14b) = 980/(1000-22b)
 Solving, b = 25/3 
a/(25/3) = 1000/[950-14*(25/3)] 
a = 10 m/s 
To run 1 km, 
A takes 100 seconds.

Question_Text: If a product is bought for Rs. 500 and sold for rs. 600, what is the profit percentage?
Solution:
Profit = SP – CP
Profit % = (Profit / CP) * 100
Profit = (600 - 500) = 100;
 Profit % = (100/500) * 100 = 20%

Question_Text: If the cost price of 12 apples is equal to the selling price of 10 apples, what is the profit percentage?
Solution:
SP of 1 apple = Rs. 1

SP of 10 apples  Rs. 10 = CP of 12 apples

Sp of 12 apples = Rs. 12 

Profit % = [(12-10)/10] * 100 = 20%

Question_Text: A shopkeeper has a loss of 10% on selling an article for Rs. 450,then find the selling price in order to get 15% profit.
If an article is sold for Rs. 750 and a profit of 25% is earned, for how much should he sell it to gain 30%?
Solution:
CP = (Initial SP) x 100/(100+P%)
CP = 750 × 100/(100 +25)
CP = Rs. 600
As he wants to sell the article at gain of 30%
Required SP = CP x (100 + P%)/100
Required SP = 600 x (100 + 30)/100 = 780
 He should sell the sweater at Rs. 780 to gain 30%

Question_Text: Hari suffered a loss of 8% by selling an article. If he had sold it for Rs. 300 more, he would have made a profit of 4%. Find his CP (in Rs.)
Solution:
Let the Cost price be 100%
Loss = (100-8)= 92%

Again, when there is a profit of 4%

Profit = (100 + 4)= 104%
Difference of an article = (104 - 92)= 12%
 12% = 300
100%=(300×100)/12
         = Rs. 2500. 
The required CP is Rs. 2500

Question_Text: The cost prices of articles A and B are Rs. 1200 and Rs. 1600 respectively. The selling price of article A is Rs. 1380 and the total profit on selling both the articles is 25%. What is the profit percentage on the selling of article B?
Solution:
The cost price of articles A and B = 1200 + 1600 = Rs. 2800
The selling price of articles A and B = cost price x (100 + profit)% = 2800 x125%
The selling price of articles A and B = Rs. 3500
The selling price of articles A + the selling price of articles B = 3500
1380 + the selling price of articles B = 3500
The selling price of articles B = Rs. 2120
 Profit % on article B = [(2120- 1600)/1600] x 100 = 520/16 = 32.5%
 The profit percentage on the selling of article B is 32.5%.

Question_Text: A product has a marked price of ₹800. Two successive discounts of 10% and 5% are given. What is the final selling price?

Question_Text: A toy is marked at ₹500. A discount of 10% is given, but the shopkeeper still makes a profit of 20%. Find the cost price.
Solution:
Selling Price = Marked Price - Discount = ₹500 - 10% of 500 = ₹500 - ₹50 = ₹450Let the Cost Price be CP.Profit% = (SP - CP)/CP × 100 = 20%
So,(450 - CP)/CP × 100 = 20=> (450 - CP) = 0.2CP=> 450 = 1.2CP=> CP = 450 / 1.2 = ₹375

Question_Text: Rohan, Mohan and Sohan decided to sell their TV, fridge and phone, respectively. The cost price of the TV was Rs. 12,775 and Rohan sold it for a profit of 12%. The cost price of the fridge was Rs. 51,100 and Mohan earned a profit of 14% by selling it. If the cost price of the phone is equal to the selling price of the TV and Sohan suffered a loss equal to half the amount of profit gained by Mohan, then what is the selling price of the phone?
Solution:
CP (TV)= Rs 12775;
SP = 112% OF 12775 = RS. 14308
CP (FRIDGE)= Rs 51100;
SP = 114% OF 51100 = RS. 58254
CP(PHONE) = SP OF TV = 14308
Sohan suffered a loss equal to half the amount of profit gained by Mohan
MOHAN’S PROFIT = 58254 – 51100 = 7154
Sohan suffered a loss equal to half the amount of profit gained by Mohan = 7154/2 = 3577
SP OF PHONE = 14308 – 3577 = 10731

Question_Text: A and B started a business by investing ₹5000 and ₹3000 respectively. After 3 months, A increased his investment by ₹500. After 6 more months, B increased his investment by ₹y. If the ratio of the profits of A to B at the end of the year is 43:40, then find the value of 5y.

A, B, and C started a business by investing Rs. 4000, Rs. 6000, and Rs. 5000 respectively. Their investment periods are n months, (n+2) months, and 10 months respectively. If the profit share of A is Rs. 1600 and the total profit is Rs. 6480, find the investment period of B.
Solution: Investments: A: ₹4000 for n months B: ₹6000 for n + 2 months C: ₹5000 for 10 months A's profit = ₹1600 Total profit = ₹6480 So, B and C together share ₹6480 – ₹1600 = ₹4880 Profits are divided in the ratio of: Investment × Time Let’s write the profit ratios: A's share ∝ 4000 × n = 4000n B's share ∝ 6000 × (n + 2) C's share ∝ 5000 × 10 = 50000 So, total profit ratio: A : B : C = 4000n : 6000(n + 2) : 50000 Let’s assume this ratio is proportional to their actual profit shares: A’s share = ₹1600 Total = ₹6480 So, let's convert the ratios to actual values: Let’s write the ratios in terms of A’s share = ₹1600 Let: 4000n = A's share → corresponds to ₹1600 Then 1 unit = ₹1600 / 4000n = ₹2/5n Now find the other shares in terms of ₹: B’s share = 6000(n+2) × (2 / 5n) C’s share = 50000 × 2 / 5n And total of B and C = ₹4880 So: 6000(n+2) × (2/5n) + 50000 × (2/5n) = 4880 Take LHS: (2/5n) [6000 (n+2) + 50000] = 4880 First compute inside the bracket: 6000 (n+2) = 6000n + 12000 ⇒ 6000n + 12000 + 50000 = 6000n + 62000 Now: (2/5n) 6000n + 62000 = 4880 Multiply both sides by 5n: 2 (6000n + 62000) = 4880 × 5n ⇒ 12000n + 124000 = 24400n 124000 = 24400n − 12000n = 12400n ⇒ n = 124000 / 12400 = 10 B invested for n + 2 = 10 + 2 = 12 months Thus, the correct answer is 12 months.

Question_Text: A invests Rs. 50,000. B joins after 3 months with Rs. 40,000 and C joins after 6 months with Rs. 60,000. Find the ratio of their profits at the end of the year
A and B start a business. After 4 months, C joins with an amount equal to A's investment. At the end of the year, C gets Rs. 3,000 as profit. What was the total profit?
Solution:
Let A invest Rs. x, B also x, C = x (after 4 months).
C’s capital × time = x × 8 = 8x
A = x × 12 = 12x
B = x × 12 = 12x
Total = 12x + 12x + 8x = 32x
C’s share = 8x/32x = 1/4
If 1/4 = 3000 → Total profit = Rs. 12,000
